argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Multiple habitability issues including mold, electrical problems, non-functioning appliances, and maintenance issues
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CA Civil Code § 1941.1, Health and Safety Code § 17920.3
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through verbal complaints, written notice on May 5, 2023, and MFH inspections
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Evidence included photos, inspection reports, witness testimony confirming long-term issues
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Significant impact on living conditions - electrical hazards, lack of heat, mold, plumbing issues affecting daily life

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Failure to maintain minimum hot water temperature required for habitable premises
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CSFRA and International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) - minimum 110 degrees Fahrenheit requirement
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, notice provided on November 23, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing Officer determined 110-degree Fahrenheit standard was appropriate based on IPMC and City's Multifamily Housing Inspection Department
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Constitutes a failure to maintain habitable premises

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Security concerns due to main gate being left open
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Board found security was compromised by gate being left open for parking convenience
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Non-residents were able to enter property, creating security risk

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Cloudy and discolored water
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, respondent had water tested by vendor
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Vendor found water was safe to drink, issue was from water supplier
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: No impact found as water was determined to be safe

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Ant/spider infestation
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: N/A
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Original petition approval maintained
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: N/A

petitions.sourceFile: 2023-01-23 Rent Boards Finding and Decisions Appeal Case 2021056 - 2070 Glen Way Apartment F.json

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Unlawful rent increases above allowed AGA and multiple increases within 12 months
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: No, landlord failed to provide required CSFRA notices
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer found rent increases unlawful due to failure to register property and exceeding AGA limits
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant was overcharged beyond legal base rent amount

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Water leak in roof leading to mold and habitability issues in garage and living room
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: Civil Code Section 1941.1(a)(1), Health & Safety Code Section 17920.3(a)(13)
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, notified on multiple occasions in December 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Photographic evidence showed visual discoloration, mold presence confirmed through testimony and documentation
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Elderly tenant unable to use living room and garage due to mold conditions

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord imposed improper 10% rent increase when property was not registered with the City
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through petition filed December 30, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Property registration record shows non-registration during rent increase period
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant was overcharged $114.40 per month for 13 months

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Secondhand smoke entering unit from neighboring tenants, affecting tenant's health and safety
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CA Civil Code § 1941.1, Mountain View Municipal Code Ch. 21, Art. II, Section 21.56
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple notices and complaints since March 2019, including Fire Department documentation
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Substantiated by Fire Department reports, tenant logs, and property manager emails confirming smoking incidents
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Severe impact on tenant's health requiring medical treatment and hospital visits

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Rat infestation in common areas
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CA Civil Code § 1941.1(a)(6), International Property Maintenance Code § 302.5
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, documented through tenant complaints and photos
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Evidence included photos of rat droppings and property manager confirmation of pest control services
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Affected common areas equivalent to 20% of rental value

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Inadequate lighting in parking lot creating safety hazard
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple email complaints and maintenance requests
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Photos documented dark conditions, property manager admitted lighting issues
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Created safety and security risks for tenants

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord failed to register property with Rent Stabilization Program as required by CSFRA
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: Rent reduction for October 7-9, 2022 plus reduction of banked increases through August 31, 2023
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, landlord was notified multiple times including September 30, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Property registration records confirmed non-compliance until October 10, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Constituted substantial noncompliance with CSFRA affecting rent increase validity

petitions.respondent: Gina Frye, Lydia Sanabria (Calson Property Management)

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Deteriorating glazing and poor condition of bathtub, shower and sinks
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, tenant informed respondent's agent/plumber
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Photographic evidence and testimony demonstrated poor conditions; respondent only offered reglazings rather than necessary repairs
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Conditions were deemed to significantly impact habitability

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Blocked parking access due to dumpster placement
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple complaints made since February 2021
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Evidence showed ongoing issue requiring new waste management company
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Significant impact on tenant's fundamental right to parking access

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Unsanitary and non-functional laundry facilities
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple reports made
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Testimony and evidence demonstrated ongoing poor conditions
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Facilities deemed inaccessible, unsafe and unsanitary

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord failed to register property with Rent Stabilization Program and imposed illegal rent increases
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, city provided notice regarding property compliance status
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Respondent did not contest factual statements by Petitioner and failed to register property until after petition filed
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant paid excess rent due to landlord's substantial non-compliance with CSFRA

petitions.respondent: Frank Cervantes aka Francisco Cervantes for Cervantes, LLC

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord miscalculated base rent and made unlawful rent increases
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, tenant contacted property manager about rent increases
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer found base rent was incorrectly calculated as $2,390 instead of $2,172.73
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant was overcharged $337.27 per month due to unlawful rent increases

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Non-functioning elevator and lighting in common areas
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CA Civil Code § 1941.1, Rent Ordinance Section 13
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through tenant complaints and prior petitions
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing Officer acknowledged elevator was out of service and lights weren't replaced timely
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Loss of elevator service and inadequate lighting deemed significant enough to warrant rent reduction

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Water overflow and mold in kitchen sink
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Woodland Park responded timely to water overflow issue
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Impact deemed addressed through timely response

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Moisture and mold issues in living room wall due to water leaks near window
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple notices starting October 2021
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Tenants' testimony and evidence found more credible than landlord's regarding timeline of repairs
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Significant reduction in property value and health impacts from humidity/mold condition

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Tenant filed for relief from banked rent increase of 5% due to financial hardship
argumentsAndDecisions.complaintTiming: Filed October 9, 2023, within 10 days of effective rent increase date
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through Notice of Rent Increase dated August 29, 2023
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer found tenant's household income was less than AMI threshold and qualified for relief
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Determined tenant would experience financial hardship if rent increase was imposed

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord's predecessor failed to roll back rent and improperly imposed 2018 Annual General Adjustment
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing Officer found sufficient evidence that predecessor failed to roll back rent from $1,850 to $1,700
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant was overcharged rent in violation of CSFRA requirements

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Water intrusion and damage to second bedroom
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple notices including June 2023
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: City inspection report confirmed water damage and needed repairs
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Bedroom constituted one-fourth of living space and became unusable

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Reduction in landscaping services
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Confirmed reduction in landscaping services
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Represented less than 3 percent of maximum legal rent

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Water intrusion and mold in second bedroom making it uninhabitable, plus structural damage to walls, ceiling and floor
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: Civil Code §1941.1 and Health and Safety Code §17920.3
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: $24,347.67 total (including rent overcharges, habitability issues, and insurance payment refunds)
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, tenant notified landlord verbally and through spouse's communications
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Photos showed substantial damage, inspection confirmed water damage, landlord admitted no repairs made
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: 25% of living space unusable, daughter unable to use bedroom, requiring space heaters and open windows to mitigate moisture

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Elimination of gardening/maintenance services without rent reduction
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: N/A
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Landlord provided no rebuttal evidence to tenant's testimony
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Reduction in housing services beyond normal wear and tear

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Insufficient hot water temperature below required minimum
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: California Health & Safety Code Section 114192, Civil Code Section 1941.1, Health & Safety Code Sections 17920.3 and 17920.10
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, notice provided on November 23, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Water temperature consistently below 120-degree minimum requirement, verified through temperature readings
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Significant impact on tenant's use of shower and ability to properly use sinks

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Improper rent increase calculation and failure to apply rent concessions
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through rent payments and documentation
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer found respondent incorrectly calculated base rent by not including concession months
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant was overcharged due to improper rent calculation

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Multiple maintenance and habitability issues including mold, peeling paint, broken appliances and flooring
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through maintenance request on August 23, 2023
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Photos and video evidence supported tenant's claims about conditions
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Issues affected habitability and potentially tenant health and safety

petitions.respondent: Ferdi DeLuna, The Arbors at Mountain View

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Lack of adequate hot water temperature below required minimum of 120 degrees
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: California Health and Safety Code Section 114192

argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Both parties agreed water temperature was at least 13 degrees below minimum requirement, documented with multiple temperature readings
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Significant impact on tenant's ability to shower and properly use sinks

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord failed to properly refund rent overcharges and security deposit, continued charging above base rent
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: $6,072.11 plus additional penalties ($177.11 for delayed refund, $50.31 for utility overcharges, $8.33 for security deposit delay)
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through original petition and compliance notices
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Documentation showed continued overcharging above base rent and delayed refunds
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenants were overcharged for 9 months and deprived of rightful refunds

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Gas heater malfunction and landlord's failure to repair, causing tenant to rely on electric heater
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: Cal. Code Regs. Tit. 25, § 34 and CSFRA Section 1710(b)(1)
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: $1,174.73 ($77.00 for electric heater + $1,097.73 for rent reductions)
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple notices including texts on April 29, 2021 and April 22, 2023
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: PG&E evaluation found no dangerous gas levels but confirmed gas leak. Landlord failed to fix despite promises and notices.
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant had to purchase electric heater and was without proper heating services for extended period

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Multiple habitability issues including gaps/cracks allowing vermin entry, kitchen repairs needed, door and window problems
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: Mountain View Municipal Code Article XVII, Section 1700
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: $46,834.50 rent refund plus $310.50 monthly rent reduction
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through text messages and direct communication
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: City inspections verified completion of repairs and compliance
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Issues affected habitability through vermin entry and cold air infiltration

petitions.rentAdjustment: Yes ($310.50 monthly reduction until repairs completed)

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord failed to register property with Rent Stabilization Program and improperly implemented rent increases
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: Rent increase amount between Sept 1-Oct 9, 2022 plus banked increases exceeding 5% AGA through Aug 31, 2023
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, landlord was notified multiple times in prior years including September 30, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: City records confirmed property was not registered until October 10, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant required to pay over 50% of income on rent, qualifying as undue hardship

petitions.respondent: Gina Frye, Lydia Sanabria (Calson Property Management)

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Water leaks causing mold in garage and damage to living room wall/floor
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: Civil Code §1941.1 and Health and Safety Code §17920.3
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, written notice provided December 12 and 17, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Photos showed significant mold growth in garage and damage to living room; landlord failed to test for mold despite visual evidence
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Conditions endangered health of elderly resident, prevented full use of garage, and caused water damage to living room

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Failure to address persistent mold growth and moisture issues in wall near living room window
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CA Health & Safety Code Section 17920.3(a)(11), Civil Code Section 1941.1
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, multiple work orders filed and maintenance visits documented
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Landlord failed to provide evidence of repairs, had inconsistent records, and could not produce photos showing completed work
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Severe health impact - AT&T worker required specialized mask, neighbor wouldn't allow child to enter premises, tenants experienced physical symptoms

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Inadequate heating system causing freezing temperatures in bedrooms and bathrooms
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through multiple written complaints starting December 19, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Tenant's testimony about freezing temperatures was uncontradicted and maintenance staff's repeated visits without resolution supported the claim
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Freezing temperatures represented a major discomfort and serious loss of tenancy benefits

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Single pane windows providing inadequate weather protection
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: No - Tenant failed to properly notify landlord about window issues
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Tenant didn't prove landlord was aware of habitability violation regarding windows
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Contributed to cold temperatures but separate from heating system issue

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord failed to comply with CSFRA registration requirements while implementing rent increases
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CSFRA Section 1707(f)(1) and CSFRA Reg. Chap. 11(B)(1) and 11(F)
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: Reduction of entire rent increase from Sept 1-Oct 9, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through multiple notices from City staff
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Evidence demonstrated landlord was non-compliant with registration requirements until October 10, 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant qualified for undue hardship relief due to income being significantly below 120% AMI

petitions.respondent: Del Medio Manor, LLP and Calson Property Management

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Tenant seeks relief from banked 5% AGA rent increase due to financial hardship
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through formal rent increase notice
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Petitioner proved income below 100% of median household income for Santa Clara County
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Hearing officer found undue hardship would result from banked rent increase due to limited income

petitions.respondent: Shoreline Village LLC rep. by Steve Welter

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Undue hardship due to rent increase exceeding tenant's ability to pay based on income
argumentsAndDecisions.violatedCode: CSFRA Sec. 1707(d) and Chapter 7, Section C
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: Full refund of rent increase from Sept 1-Oct 9, 2022; reduction of banked increases exceeding 5% AGA through Aug 31, 2023
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through formal petition process
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Tenant provided credible evidence of income significantly below AMI threshold of $117,950
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant's income proven to be significantly below 100% of median household income, demonstrating undue hardship

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord failed to register property with rent stabilization program
argumentsAndDecisions.reimbursement: No rent increases permitted during non-compliance period (before Oct 10, 2022)
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, documented in HO Ex. 7, 8, and 9
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: City records confirmed non-compliance with registration requirements
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Registration non-compliance prevented landlord from implementing any rent increases

petitions.respondent: Del Medio Manor, LLP and Calson Property Management

argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing Officer's inspection confirmed cracked/uneven patio with no visual evidence of claimed repairs
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Conditions more than minor maintenance deficiency but not a habitability violation

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord's failure to register unit and unlawful imposition of utility charges
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, tenant made complaints about utility charges
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer found landlord failed to properly register unit and unlawfully imposed utility charges
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenant was charged above maximum lawful rent and forced to pay utilities that should have been included

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Water leak in basement causing severe odor and flooding
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, reported in April 2022
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Evidence showed issue persisted longer than landlord claimed based on CLESEPA letter from 2021
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenants unable to use kitchen, forced to wash dishes outside, visitors reluctant to enter due to smell

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Broken windows and structural gaps allowing pest entry
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, documented in City inspection reports
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: City inspection reports confirmed issues
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Affected weatherproofing and pest control of unit

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Severe pest infestation (cockroaches and rats)
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, reported since December 2020
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Monthly pest control was insufficient to resolve the issue
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Severe habitability violation with long-term persistence

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Lack of hot water/faulty water heater
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, reported in 2016
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Confirmed lack of hot water for extended period
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Major violation of habitability affecting basic living conditions

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Tenant seeks relief from banked rent increases due to senior status and limited income
argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through proper petition filing process
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Petitioner proved by preponderance of evidence senior status and income below 120% AMI threshold
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Undue hardship would result from banked rent increases due to senior status and limited income

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Incorrect base rent calculation leading to unlawful rent increases in 2022 and 2023

argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer found base rent was incorrectly calculated by not including rent concessions from initial term
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenants were overcharged due to incorrect base rent calculation

argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Additional deposit was improperly characterized as security deposit rather than pet deposit
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenants paid excess security deposit beyond lawful amount

argumentsAndDecisions.respondentHadNotice: Yes, through filed petition and hearing process
argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer analyzed detailed rent payment records and determined incorrect base rent calculations
argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Tenants were overcharged due to improper rent calculation and multiple unlawful rent increases

argumentsAndDecisions.complaintSummary: Landlord failed to register property with Rent Stabilization Program and imposed unlawful rent increases

argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Long-term maintenance issue affecting habitability

argumentsAndDecisions.impactAssessment: Disturbs peaceful enjoyment but outside maintenance/habitability scope

argumentsAndDecisions.evidenceAssessment: Hearing officer found substantial evidence of ongoing smoking issues despite respondent's efforts to address it
